{"status":"ok","message-type":"work","message-version":"1.0.0","message":{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2024,5,9]],"date-time":"2024-05-09T18:39:19Z","timestamp":1715279959122},"reference-count":7,"publisher":"American Economic Association","content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"short-container-title":["AEA Papers and Proceedings"],"published-print":{"date-parts":[[2023,5,1]]},"abstract":"<jats:p>The COVID-19 pandemic increased the rate of mental health disorders, as well as demand for mental health services. It remains unclear, however, the extent to which it impacted access to mental health care. Using data from an audit field experiment, which ran from January to May 2020 and overlapped with the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, we examine the impact of COVID-19 on access to mental health care appointments in the United States. We find that increased intensity of COVID-19\u2013measured by daily cases, daily fatalities, and weekly excess deaths\u2013is associated with decreased access to mental health care appointments.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.1257\/pandp.20231058","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2023,5,23]],"date-time":"2023-05-23T13:54:15Z","timestamp":1684850055000},"page":"420-422","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":2,"title":["The Impact of COVID-19 on Access to Mental Health Care Services"],"prefix":"10.1257","volume":"113","author":[{"given":"Benjamin","family":"Harrell","sequence":"first","affiliation":[{"name":"Vanderbilt LGBTQ Policy Lab, Vanderbilt University (email: )"}]},{"given":"Luca","family":"Fumarco","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[{"name":"Masaryk University, IZA, and GLO (email: )"}]},{"given":"Patrick","family":"Button","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[{"name":"Tulane University, NBER, J-PAL, and IZA (email: )"}]},{"given":"David J.","family":"Schwegman","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[{"name":"School of Public Affairs, American University (email: )"}]},{"given":"Kyla","family":"Denwood","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[{"name":"Carnegie Endowment for International Peace (email: )"}]}],"member":"11","reference":[{"key":"p_1","unstructured":"American Psychological Association (APA). 2021. \"Worsening Mental Health Crisis Pressures Psychologist Workforce.\" 2021 COVID-19 Practitioner Survey.
